title: Circles
goals: Identify parts of a circle and find circumference
Calculate area of circles, arc lengths, and sector areas
Apply the Inscribed Angle Theorem and related theorems
Use circle theorems involving chords, tangents, and secants
instructionalStrategy: Build from circumference (C = 2πr) to arc length (fraction of circumference) to sector area (fraction of total area).
The central angle is the 'fraction control knob'—θ/360 determines what fraction of the whole circle you're measuring.
Inscribed angles are always half the central angle that subtends the same arc—use this as the 'master theorem' that unlocks the rest.
Tangent lines are always perpendicular to the radius at the point of tangency—draw the radius first, then the tangent.

scaffold.text:
A **circle** is the set of all points equidistant from a center point. Key vocabulary:

• **Radius (r)** — segment from center to any point on the circle
• **Diameter (d)** — segment through the center connecting two points on the circle (d = 2r)
• **Chord** — segment connecting any two points on the circle
• **Secant** — a line that intersects a circle at two points
• **Tangent** — a line that touches the circle at exactly one point
• **Arc** — a portion of the circle between two points
• **Central angle** — angle with vertex at the center
• **Inscribed angle** — angle with vertex on the circle

**Circumference:** C = 2πr = πd
**Area:** A = πr²
scaffold.initialPrompt: A circle has a diameter of 10 inches. What is the radius? Can you find the circumference and area?

scaffold.problem: A circle has a radius of 7 cm. Find the circumference and area.
scaffold.explanation:
**Circumference:**
C = 2πr = 2π(7) = 14π ≈ 43.98 cm

**Area:**
A = πr² = π(7²) = 49π ≈ 153.94 cm²

Notice the key difference:
• Circumference uses r (linear → gives a length)
• Area uses r² (squared → gives square units)

Always leave answers in terms of π when possible (exact form) unless told to approximate.
scaffold.initialPrompt: What happens to the circumference and area if we double the radius to 14 cm? Does each one double?

scaffold.text:
**Arc Length** and **Sector Area** are fractions of the whole circle, controlled by the central angle:

**Arc Length** = (θ/360°) × 2πr
This is the fraction (θ/360°) of the full circumference.

**Sector Area** = (θ/360°) × πr²
This is the fraction (θ/360°) of the full area.

Think of it like a pizza: the central angle determines what fraction of the pizza (circle) you're taking. A 90° slice is 90/360 = 1/4 of the pizza.
scaffold.initialPrompt: A pizza has a 12-inch diameter. If you cut a slice with a 60° central angle, what fraction of the whole pizza is that slice?

scaffold.problem: A circle has radius 10 cm. Find the arc length and sector area for a central angle of 72°.
scaffold.explanation:
**Fraction of the circle:** 72/360 = 1/5

**Arc Length:**
= (72/360) × 2π(10)
= (1/5) × 20π
= 4π ≈ 12.57 cm

**Sector Area:**
= (72/360) × π(10²)
= (1/5) × 100π
= 20π ≈ 62.83 cm²

Both are exactly 1/5 of the whole circumference and area, respectively.
scaffold.initialPrompt: If the central angle were 144° instead (double 72°), would the arc length and sector area also exactly double?

problems.question: A circle has radius 9 inches. Find the arc length for a central angle of 120°.
A sector has an area of 25π cm² and the circle has radius 10 cm. Find the central angle.
hints: Total area = π(10²) = 100π. The sector is 25π/100π = 1/4 of the circle.

problems.question: A circle has radius 6 ft. Find the area of a sector with a central angle of 150°.

scaffold.initialPrompt: For the first problem, what fraction of the whole circle does a 120° angle represent?

scaffold.text:
**Inscribed Angle Theorem:** An inscribed angle (vertex on the circle) is **half** the central angle that intercepts the same arc.

If a central angle = 80°, an inscribed angle intercepting the same arc = 40°.

**Key Corollaries:**
• Inscribed angles that intercept the SAME arc are congruent
• An inscribed angle that intercepts a semicircle (diameter) = 90°
• Opposite angles of an inscribed quadrilateral are supplementary (sum to 180°)

**Tangent-Radius Relationship:** A tangent line is always **perpendicular** to the radius drawn to the point of tangency.
scaffold.initialPrompt: If a triangle is inscribed in a circle and one side is a diameter, what must the angle opposite that diameter be? Why?

problems.question: A central angle measures 140°. What is the measure of an inscribed angle that intercepts the same arc?
hints: The Inscribed Angle Theorem says the inscribed angle is half the central angle.

problems.question: An inscribed angle measures 55°. What is the measure of the intercepted arc?
hints: The intercepted arc = 2 × the inscribed angle.

problems.question: Quadrilateral ABCD is inscribed in a circle. ∠A = 85°. Find ∠C.
hints: Opposite angles of an inscribed quadrilateral are supplementary.

scaffold.initialPrompt: For the first problem, what is the relationship between a central angle and an inscribed angle that intercept the same arc?

problems.question: A circle has diameter 26 cm. Find the circumference and area.
Find the arc length for a circle with radius 15 m and central angle of 80°.
A sector of a circle with radius 8 has an area of 16π. Find the central angle.
An inscribed angle intercepts a semicircle. What is the measure of the inscribed angle?
hints: A semicircle has a central angle of 180°. The inscribed angle is half: 90°.

problems.question: A tangent line meets a radius at the point of tangency. The tangent makes a 35° angle with a chord drawn from the point of tangency. Find the arc intercepted by the chord and tangent.
hints: The angle between a tangent and chord = half the intercepted arc. So arc = 2 × 35° = 70°.
